turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm only asking because it's a dangerous building. There's been some robberies, a woman was raped not long ago. This woman I'm seeing, she'll want to talk to me all day, but if I can point to you out the window and say you're waiting, I can be out quick. if anything happens, I'll be in apartment 16M.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Maybe I should come up with you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: If I'm not back in fifteen minutes, hit the buzzer. That way she'll let me go.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Nothing's going to happen. I'll come with you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, I'll be fine. I'm just visiting a sick friend.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I shouldn't have asked you to come.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You asked me not to come.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Promise you won't go inside.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Fifteen minutes.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I just have to relax a little. Not feel so guilty all the time.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We can still go back. I'll walk you home. You sleep a couple of hours, watch some TV, take a bath.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't be a cop. If you have any doubts about this, it's my fault.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Mary. Mary, we've got to get going.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, no.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You and CY have a nice talk? He tell you about Sunrise Enterprises, helping people? Well, I've seen him hurt people. Why are you following me?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Because you can barely walk.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What is it? You want to help me, you feel sorry for me? Keep it to yourself.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I need to sit down a minute.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Or maybe you wanna fuck me? Everyone else has.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I heard CY Coates was brought in. He looked pretty bad.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He'll be all right.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Too bad. He called me up today, can you believe that? I don't know how he got my number. He asks me do I want to come over and see him, I tell him I'd rather go to a leper colony. He says there's a new gang that wants to kill him, take over the business. I told him I hope he's right. That they kill him. That's what I told him.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It'll be a while before he's up and running again.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: OK, last night I was weak. it won't happen again. And all that shit I said--it was just because I was stoned. Forget it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No problem. Thanks for letting me crash. It was the best sleep I've had in months. I used some of your soap.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I wish these people would leave already. I can't listen to another story. Did you see him?  That doctor says the brain is coming around. They're waiting for the heart to stabilize. I don't know who to believe. He says they still have to keep him tied up.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Can I bring you something back to eat--a falafal, some pizza?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, we just ate. I only remember how tough my father was. Now I know he had to be like that, to make us tough. This city'll kill you if you aren't strong enough.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No, the city doesn't discriminate. It gets everybody.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: This is not a good time.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: There's no time.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Frank.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Come on up.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: My Lord mother man, you look like hell. What were you drinking?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: The captain almost fired me tonight. I'm on my way out. Anytime now.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Nobody gets fired. Look at me. Only thing they might do is transfer you to the Bronx. You look like you aged ten years since I rode with you last.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: The ghosts--

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: You ever notice people who see shit always, are crazy?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I think the worst is over.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: It can always get worse. You can't change what's out there, only where you're coming from. You got to let the Lord take over, in here.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: She only works when I'm on. I make her wait and it drives her crazy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Is it true that you and Love went on a blind date?  She hit you with a bottle?

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: She loves me the way no woman ever has.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's not dead. It's a heroin overdose. Break out the Narcon.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: He's dead unless you folks want to stop bullshitting me and tell it straight. Then, Lord willing, we'll try to bring him back.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: I ever tell you about the time years ago I was on this ledge uptown, trying to talk this psycho inside?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Where the guy jumped and you almost fell. No, you never told me that story.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: No, you never listened. I was going, man, if someone on high hadn't pulled me in. I had put all I had into saving this dumbass lowlife suicidal that when he went down, there was a part of me that wanted to go with him.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Make a left here. I want to stop.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Who's that?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: She's the daughter of a cardiac arrest I brought in last night. I told her we'd give her a ride back to Misery. Her father's showing signs of improving.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Oh, Frank, you've got it bad, so much worse than I thought.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm hungry too. We gotta get some food after this.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: God help us, he's hungry too.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Went over to Sal's got this. There must be some place in Hell for a guy who sells a dollar-fifty a slice. I call you if anything comes up.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Rule number one: Don't get involved with patients. Rule number two: Don't get involved with patient's daughters. You understand?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What about rule number three: Don't get involved with dispatchers named Love.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: You don't know the first thing about rule number three, cannot begin to understand the complexities of that rule. Come on, let's go look at some hookers. The Kit Kat will be letting out.  Don't ever call a junkie whore a crackhead. They get real mad.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Nice though, pulling back her hood as we drive by. There's a mystery to it, then she shows you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: She's no whore, Marcus.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: We're all whores, Frank. You know what I'm talking about, the way she looked at me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: She wasn't looking at you, man, she was looking at me.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: No, you didn't, Frank, thank you. But there's still a couple hours left on the shift.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I need a drink, that's all.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Look at that. A fat junkie. That's a first.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What's wrong.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's coming.  Hold her down.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: What's that, Frank?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Three legs.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: That's too many.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Backup?

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: It's coming.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Don't give me that look.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: What look?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You know what I'm talking about. It's all over your face. That I-just- saved-a-little-baby-boy look.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: We just saved a little baby boy. Think of it that way.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't want to hear about it, okay? That's three jobs for the night. It's over. Three jobs and time for a drink. Six am, the cocktail hour. Pass the bottle; I know you're holding.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I hate vodka.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Please, a little decorum if you will. What I was going to say is, is that holding that baby in my arms, I felt like I was twenty-one again. A call like that makes me think of going back to three nights a week, not two, start running again, cut down on the drinking.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'll drink to that.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Here's to the greatest job in the world.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Greatest job in the world.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Where you going?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I quit! I'm through!

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: You can't leave me now.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He got better.

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: I hate pronouncing people dead over the phone.  Better, huh? They're fixed and dilated. He's plant food.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He one of them?

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: No, that's Noel. Used to be a regular off and on, hasn't been in in a while. He seized and almost coded--I gave him a hypertonic solution. He drank so much the kidneys were taking out salt. One for the textbooks.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That guy I brought in yesterday, post-cardiac arrest. He's gone.

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: Burke. You won't believe it. He's showing cognitive signs. He started with spontaneous respiration, now he's fighting to pull out the tube. Had to sedate him. He's in a CAT scan. I'm giving him every test I can: thromboytics, steroids, nitrodrips, heparin.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: Who knows? It's all lower-brain-stem- activity. The heart refuses to stabilize--he's coded eleven times since he got here. This guy's a fighter. Every time the Valium wears off he starts yanking those restraints.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: The family know?

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: I wanted to bring them in, to see if he'd respond to voices, but they weren't in the waiting room. The guy's daughter was in my face all last night and when I finally have something positive to tell her, she's gone.

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: Oh Jesus, put her on the monitor. Where's the pediatric code cart?  Odette give me that tube. All right, flatline--let's do CPR. step back, Frank. How many months?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Can't tell. It was a breech, twins. The other one seems okay, though. Marcus is taking him and the mother to Maternity.

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: You can't believe how much he's improved.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How many times have you shocked him tonight?

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: Fourteen. We finally got him a room upstairs. Should be up there in a couple of hours.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What do you do, just have someone follow him around with a defribilator?

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: That's good, Frank. No, but they might surgically implant one, about the size of my thumb. It goes near the shoulder here, with two electrodes connected to the heart. It sends a shock whenever it senses a drop in blood flow. Amazing, isn't it?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: A medical miracle.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Last show of the night.

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: Jesus Christ. Nurse Crupp!  Anybody else hurt?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: Crazy fucker.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Where's Burke?

turns.speaker: HAZMAT
turns.text: Upstairs. 212. Had to shock him twice more.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's dead, Rose. Your father passed.

turns.speaker: ROSE/MARY
turns.text: How can that be? He was getting better.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He coded. They shocked him one too many times. I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: ROSE/MARY
turns.text: He was tough. You did all you could.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: ROSE/MARY
turns.text: You have to keep the body going until the brain and heart recover enough to go on their own.

turns.speaker: ROSE/MARY
turns.text: Would you like to come in?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's not worth it, Tom. He's surrendering.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: No prisoners. Don't worry, Frank, just a little psychological first aid.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm sick, Tom. I need a cure.  Vitamin B cocktail, followed by an amp of glucose and a drop of adrenaline. Not as good as beer, but all I got.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Come on, Frank. There's blood spilling in the streets.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: These are hard times, Tom.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Yeah. Great, isn't it?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Great to be drunk. Sobriety's killing me.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Look up, Frank. Full moon. The blood's gonna run tonight. I can feel it. Our mission: to save lives.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Our mission is coffee, Tom. A shot of the bull, Puerto Rican espresso.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Ten-four. El Toro de Oro. Blast off.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: The cure's not working, Tom. Maybe we should go back to the hospital.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Don't worry, kid. Tom'll take care of you. Put your head out the window, get some of that summer air. Listen to the music. El Toro de Oro. Andale. Pronto.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Tom, where are the Band-aids? This is an ambulance, isn't it?

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Look out!

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Where you going?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: C'mon, Tom. The city's burning.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Whatja doing?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I feel the need, the need for speed. I'm driving out of myself.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: The brakes are shot.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I've taken that into consideration.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I never felt better in my life.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Mr. Oh.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's early for him.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: That's all right, we're not meant to do Oh tonight. Something is going to happen. I can feel it.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Whadda we bring?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Better bring it all.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Get this, Frank--we got two patients. Number one, the scarecrow outside. Number two misses the railing but breaks both legs on the balcony, then throws himself through a glass window, heads to the bedroom, where he's now passed out.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Well, he's the steakhead of the night, then.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: I don't think the fire people can touch him out there.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How's he doing?

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: I haven't had a chance to see him yet. I'm going to take care of sleeping beauty.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Get ready, Frank. Missed a drug shooting while you were dicking around in there. There's gonna be trauma tonight!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: As long as we keep moving. No standing still.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: C'mon, look at your screen. Give up some blood!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: C'mon, Tom, pick up a job.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: You want some bum in the bus terminal? We'll wait for a real call.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Let's get in a fight, then.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Who with?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's your job. Just keep driving, keep moving. No stopping. We're sharks. We stop too long, we die.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Let's break something, Tom. Let's bust something, bomb something.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: What do you want to break?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't know--let's break some windows.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Destruction, distraction. I feel the need.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: You need a reason, Frank. You don't just go around breaking people's windows. That's anarchy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What's the reason? Give me a reason, Tom.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Let me think.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: This guy's been terrorizing the neighborhood for weeks, ever since he got outta jail, wreaking general havoc, contributing to the bad name of the place. The term "menace to society" was made up for him.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's crazy. He can't help it.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Well, why don't they put him away? Prisons don't want him. I took him to the hospital yesterday and here he is again.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Look at that. Tell me that's a crazy person. Every move is calculated. He knows exactly what he's doing. This is the guy. I've been after him for weeks. He's quick, runs like a rat, tough for one person, but with two of us--

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay, whatta I do?

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: If he sees me, he'll run, so I'll get out here. You start talking to him about baseball or something while I sneak around behind and get down and you push him. When he falls we get him.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's ridiculous.

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Believe me, it always works. The simpler, the better.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You learn that in the army?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Get the kit! We're gonna tube him!

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Frank!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Do it!

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: Frank!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We're gonna save you, Noel. You're gonna be all right.  Do it, Tom! I'll call for fucking backup, I swear!

turns.speaker: WALLS
turns.text: You're crazy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No we can't. He's got a pulse.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: No shit.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: The Chinese close in five minutes. Beef lo mein. It's  been on my mind since I woke. Whatjathink?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I think the moment that food hits your mouth we'll get a job.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Turn here. You missed it. The Chink is on 3rd.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Oh no!--I just remembered.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: I'm so stupid. I had beef lo mein last night. I can't eat the same thing two nights in a row. It's almost two o'clock, what the hell am I gonna do? What you getting?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm not hungry.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Oh yeah, you don't eat food.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I eat. I just haven't had coffee yet.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Coffee and whiskey, lucky you ain't dead with that diet. Wait, I've got it. Half fried chicken with fries. Let's go, hurry up. Come on.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Turn it off.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You know what. The radio.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You wanted it turned off. There's no such thing as a good fire. People get burned up. They can't breathe.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: That's what we're here for. Come on, Frank.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Don't push it, Larry.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You're burned out.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Mr. Oh.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: It's Mr. Oh. I'm not answering it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Relax, it's a street job, easy except for the smell. We'll just throw him in back and zip over to Mercy--no blood, no dying, that's how I look at it. He's just a drunk.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: It's not our job to taxi drunks around.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: They'll just keep calling.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Someone's gonna die someday causa that bum, going to have a cardiac and the only medics will be taking care of Mr. Oh.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Well why didn't you say so?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: He's drunk.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Faster! God!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Faster!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Larry, swing over on Eighth. We're gonna hafta run one of these calls.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Relax, will you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm not feeling very well, Larry. I say we go back to the hospital and call it a night.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You have no sick time, Frank. No time of any kind. Everyone knows that.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Take me back, put me to bed; I surrender. We've done enough damage tonight.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You take things too seriously. Look at us, we're cruising around, talking, taking some quiet time, getting paid for it. We've got a good job here.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah, you're right.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Tell me, you ever think of doing anything else?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Sure, I'm taking the captain's exam next year. After the kids are in school, Louise can go back to the post office and, I thought, what the hell, I'll start my own medic service. Out on the Island the volunteers are becoming salaried municipal. It's just a matter of time and who you know. Someday it's going to be Chief Larry calling the shots.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: He's crazy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You really think so?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Jesus, Tom Walls, that crazy motherfucker.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Used to be my partner.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You're in the stomach!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You sure?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You're in the stomach! Let me try.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: One more time!

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Stomach again.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No way!

turns.speaker: RADIO DISPATCHER
turns.text: One-three Zebra. Zebra three, I need you.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You see, he's giving it to us anyway.

turns.speaker: RADIO DISPATCHER
turns.text: Zebra, are you there? I'm holding an unconscious at First and St. Marks.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: No! It's three o'clock. That can only mean one thing.

turns.speaker: RADIO DISPATCHER
turns.text: Answer the radio Zebra. You know it's that time.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Four times this week I've had him. Aren't there any other units out there?  Don't answer the radio. They'll give it to someone else.

turns.speaker: RADIO DISPATCHER
turns.text: Thirteen Zebra. One-Three Zebra. You're going out of service in two seconds.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Look, Frank, when I say don't answer it, that means answer it.  You can do that for me at least.  Three Zebra.

turns.speaker: RADIO DISPATCHER
turns.text: Yes, Zebra. You'll be driving to the man who needs no introduction, chronic caller of the year three straight and shooting for number four. The duke of drunk, the king of stink, our most frequent flier, Mr. Oh.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Ten-four.  Don't go. Not this time.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Shit, shit, shit...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You're almost there, you can do it -- can do -- can do.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Okay if I watch you tape that interview downstairs?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: One source referred to it as a five billion dollar metal sculpture to ugly to look at and too big to bury.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: You write this?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: ...outlaw nation but strangely those who have interviewed Gaddafi find him, in a phrase we like to use in this country, very 'presidential'.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Nice, Jane.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Hi, Aaron...What's doing?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Same old stuff.  I'm watching a man who won three Overseas Press Awards pitch an hors d'oeuvre idea.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You want to go out there --  get out of this for a second?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Why don't you lead?  I'll just follow the flurry you cause.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What did I do to you?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: You've made my dreams silly.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: How <u>you</u> doing?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Great.  Network news, Washington... I love it.  What do you do when your real life exceeds your dreams?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Keep it to yourself.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You know the other day I really wanted your reaction to how we did with the Libyan report -- I was going to ask but I guess I feel a little intimidated with you.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Oh, stop it.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: You can't talk about feeling intimidated when you're on top of the world.  It's unseemly.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I'm not buying into any of that.  I have a load to learn.  I'm not going to act as if...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: You have the job you have...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Shut up a second...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Okay.  Pretty petty party, isn't it, pal?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I made one rule for myself when this started and I realized I was going to take a lot from you people because of being from sports...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: And the rule was...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Never to pretend to know more than I did.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Can you name all the members of the Cabinet?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Okay, let's drop it.  I didn't mean I'd take a test for you -- I mean if that came up in conversation I'd...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: We're conversing...Oh my, the names of the entire Cabinet has slipped my mind.  What are they?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Don't name them.  Just tell me if you know.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yes, Aaron.  I know the names of the Cabinet.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: There are only ten.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You're feeling good, aren't you?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I'm starting to... We may do the capitols of the states.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Fifty, right?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I'm in a pissy mood.  I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What's wrong with it?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Nothing.  I think you really blew the lid off nookie.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: This is uncomfortable for me -- because, well, I don't mean it as a knock, but we approach this differently.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: We sure do.  I don't mean it as a knock either.  Go ahead.  I'll just say what I think and you can disregard it if you want.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: It just might not work for me because of our different approaches.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Wait.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Your coat jacket is rising up in back.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I don't like being handled.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Sit on it!  <u>Now</u> look.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Just don't physically...  Fantastic tip -- fantastic.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No.  That's not going to tell us anything.  Let's get this prompter going.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: It's not loaded.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I'll find some copy.  Be right back.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No.  No.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: No?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Don't let your eyes go from the beginning of the sentence to the end like that.  You don't want to look shifty, do you?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Oh, God, no!

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: And the left side of your face is the good one.  Go again.  And try to punch one word or phrase in every sentence -- punch one idea a story.  Punch -- come on --

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You were smokin' toward the end there.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: The pointers were great.  I'll study the tape.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Everybody has one like that.  I thought it was great when you started to laugh at the end.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Yeah -- well, I'm sorry I'm tying up Jane, I didn't realize you two would be going this late.  Sorry.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No.  Don't worry about it.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I'll put her on.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: What did they do with you?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: They booted me out of Washington.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Impossible.  There's no system that wouldn't value one of us.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Why?  What did they do to you?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You packing up tonight?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Yes.  And I'm sorry that they're sending you down for a while, but you'll make it back...Where they sending you?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: London.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: London.  That's a promotion!

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: It is.  Yes -- that's where they had Rorish, for God's sake, before they made him anchor.  I can't stand it -- they're grooming you for it all and you don't even know it.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Hold it down, okay?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Can I ask you something?  You only had one crew on the date rape piece, right?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yes.  You're not going to stick around for the farewell party?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: No.  I don't know how much fun it will be when Martin Klein and Ernie have to drop off their credentials with the security guard.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: This story they won't cover.  And if the network doesn't cover it -- it must not be important so why worry.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I'm going to miss you -- you're a prick in a great way...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You know what I...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: No, I liked the way it made me sound. Okay.  Be good.  So long.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, this kid couldn't possibly belong to anyone else.  What's your name?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I'm just bringing him over to give Jane a look at him --

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I thought she'd be here.  I'll go with you.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I'll see you back at the hotel.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: He excels at gratitude.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Are you any closer to a decision?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: It's nice to see you.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Congratulations on history's longest winning streak.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: If you ever get restless in Portland, let me know.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: It's Mr. Buddy Felton?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: That's your full name?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I might as well ask you the questions on tape.  Is that all right?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: You worked at one time as Foreign Service Trainee in the State Department.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I was there two years and was promoted on merit nine times.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Eventually rising to...

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Office Bimbo.  No, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: You're saying the fact that you're gay had something directly to do with your promotions?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I don't like the word gay.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Which would you prefer?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Ravenous homosexual.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Stop the tape, okay.  Forget it, Ellen.  Let's call security and get him out.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Hi.  Turn on your TV... <u>Good Morning America</u>, the <u>Morning News</u> and <u>Today</u> are all about to talk to Arnold Schwarzenegger and I think he's live on at least two of them.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: At six o'clock on the wake-up news they used the wrong missile graphic.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Now listen, Arnold just said that he's been making three million a movie now.  But he's not ever gonna change.  He's still the same person when he was making two million dollars a movie.  He feels no different.  He also bought a brand- new condo with Maria, they gonna furnish tastefully.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: A half hour in the lobby.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Okay, I'll see you in the lobbies [sic].
